titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lithographs and Charts of George Vancouver's Expeditions 1798
Lithographs and Charts of George Vancouver's Expeditions
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rainbow Koehl

publicationstmt.publisher: Western Washington University, Center for Pacific Northwest Studies

profiledesc.creation: Original finding aid was created by Rainbow Koehl, with later revisions by CPNWS staff 2015-03-18

change.item: Revision to reflect transfer of rare book materials.

did.unittitle: Lithographs and Charts of Captain George Vancouver's Expeditions
did.abstract: Thirty-four charts and lithograph illustrations documenting the expeditions of Captain George Vancouver in the Pacific Northwest and South Pacific.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Captain George Vancouver (1757-1798) was a member of the second British exploratory voyage led by Captain James Cook (1828-1779), and was also aboard the Discovery, which accompanied the Resolution on Cook’s third voyage. In 1791 Vancouver was given command of the ship the Discovery (named in honor of Cook) to chart the Pacific Northwest coast and to help resolve the crisis precipitated by John Meares at Nootka. He remained on the coast or in the Sandwich Islands for three seasons until he sailed back to England 1795.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains charts and lithographs documenting voyages by British Naval officer George Vancouver in the late eighteenth century.

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to the public (special handling required and advance notice or appointments requested).

prefercite.p: Lithographs and Charts of George Vancouver's Expeditions, Center for Pacific Northwest Studies, Western Libraries Archives & Special Collections, Western Libraries, Western Washington University, Bellingham WA 98225-9123.

processinfo.p: This collection has been renamed to reflect the transfer of rare book materials to Special Collections (and to more accurately describe the nature of the remaining materials). Previous collection titles: Bullitt collection on 18th century explorers; Lithographs and Charts of George Vancouver's Expeditions.

processinfo.head: About Harmful Language and Content
processinfo.p: Objects in this collection include depictions of Indigenous Peoples that may be considered harmful or offensive, and also present a problematic narrative of European "discovery".To learn more about problematic content in our collections, collection description and teaching tools (including how to provide feedback or request dialogue on this topic), see the following Statement About Potentially Harmful Language and Content

acqinfo.p: Priscilla Collins and Harriet Bullitt, Dorothy Bullitt’s daughters, donated the collection in 1992.

relatedmaterial.p: The Guide to the Dorothy Stimson Bullitt papers can be found at the University of Washington Libraries Special Collections in Seattle.

custodhist.p: The charts and lithographs described in this guide were part of a larger selection of rare books collected by Dorothy Stimson Bullitt (1892-1989) and donated to the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies by her daughters, Priscilla Collins and Harriet Bullitt, in 1992. Bullitt, founder of the founder of the King Broadcasting Company, is known for her pioneering work in radio and television, as well as involvement in civic matters and the arts. The original donation to the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies included a range of bound rare books and accounts of early eighteenth century exploration. The majority of these books have now been transferred to Western Libraries Special Collections and are part of its rare book collection. At least some of the remaining, oversize charts and lithographs are believed once to have been bound together.

separatedmaterial.p: Bound journals documenting the expeditions of Captains John Byron, Samuel Wallis, Philip Carteret, James Cook, John Meares, Nathaniel Portlock and George Vancouver (originally donated alongside these charts and lithographs - and from which some of the described materials may have been separated), are now housed and available at Special Collections, Western Libraries Archives & Special Collections, Western Washington University.

altformavail.p: Content from this collection has been digitized and can be accessed online as part of Western Libraries' Digital collections. See: https://mabel.wwu.edu/islandora/object/wwu%3A22286.
